repnme.cdata!:
Zambia - Economic Recovery and Investment
            Promotion, Second Economic and Social Adjustment, and Public
            Sector Reform and Export Promotion Credit Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The audit downgrades project outcomes by
            the Implementation Completion Report (ICR), rating the
            Economic Recovery and Investment Promotion Credit (ERIPC) as
            moderately satisfactory, the Second Economic and Social
            Adjustment Credit (SESAC) as unsatisfactory, and the Public
            Sector Reform and Export Promotion Credit (PSREPC)
            moderately satisfactory; however, sustainability ratings
            gave mixed results, for the audit upgrades sustainability
            for the ERIPC from uncertain to likely, though downgrades it
            to unlikely for both the SESAC and PSREPC projects, while
            institutional development impacts are rated modest in all
            three projects. Major lessons o f general applicability are
            conveyed as follows. When pressures to maintain a Client
            current on the service of its external debt, have a major
            impact on lending decisions, it is incumbent upon Management
            to discuss these pressures, and any impact they had on the
            timing, content, and size of a proposed operation with the
            Board at the time of loan presentation. "Stroke of the
            pen" measures are an unreliable indicator of Borrower
            commitment to undertaking deeper structural reform. Uneven
            macroeconomic performance sharply reduces the expected
            long-term benefits of structural reform, and cripples the
            prospects for private sector-led growth. Efforts to
            diversify Zambia's production base have not succeeded,
            in part because non-price constraints, such as poor
            infrastructure, weak governance, and public sector
            inefficiency, have not been adequately addressed.

2684258.trustfund:
TF020350-DANISH CONSULTANTS TRUST FUND,TF020400-NETHERLANDS' CONSULTANTS
            TRUST FUND,TF035494-ZAMBIA - PUBLIC SECTOR REFORM,TF035561-ZAMBIA - PUBLIC SECTOR REFORM,
            EXPORT PROMOTION,TF039354-ZAMBIA - PUBLIC SECTOR REFORM
            & EXPORT PROMO CREDIT

repnme.cdata!:
Zambia - Public Sector Reform and Export
            Promotion Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project is
            rated satisfactory, and project sustainability is rated as
            likely. Both World Bank and Borrower performances were rated
            overall satisfactory. However, viewed in the context of the
            entire reform program of the 1990's, the costly delays
            in privatizing the Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines (ZCCM)
            make Borrower rating unsatisfactory. Lessons learned include
            the following: Dealing with deep-seated problems of weak
            technical and managerial capacity and governance such as
            those faced by Zambia requires operations that combine
            sectoral focus and technical assistance/institution building
            features, longer time horizons and quick disbursements.
            Timing and strategy of privatization should be geared to
            country circumstances; the implicit privatization strategy
            followed here was to pursue the smaller, less controverisal
            privatizations first, leaving the technically and
            politically difficult, but more meaningful privatizations
            earlier. Policy advice and conditionality involving trade
            reform should consider the regional context. Because its
            main regional trading partners lagged in their trade reform,
            the benefits of Zambia's own trade reforms were
            limited, relative to the high fiscal costs. Given existing
            weaknesses of budgetary procedures and processes, specifying
            budget allocations for social sector ministries and programs
            will not ensure that funds are received by the ministries or
            spent for purposes intended.

1346362.trustfund:
TF039354-ZAMBIA - PUBLIC SECTOR REFORM
            & EXPORT PROMO CREDIT,TF035561-ZAMBIA - PUBLIC SECTOR REFORM,
            EXPORT PROMOTION,TF035494-ZAMBIA - PUBLIC SECTOR REFORM

repnme.cdata!:
Zambia - Public Sector Reform and Export
            Promotion Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Public Sector Reform and Export
            Promotion Credit Project will support measures that will: a)
            facilitate completion of the privatization of the copper
            parastatal by assisting in its labor reduction program; b)
            improve the performance of the public service by reforming
            pay and employment practices and improving management
            controls; c) promote private investment by improving access
            to imported inputs and streamlining investment approvals;
            and d) strengthen the delivery of social services by
            monitoring budget allocations to key social expenditure
            categories and supporting key policy reforms. The credit
            will bring about faster economic growth, employment
            creation, and poverty reduction. There are two possible
            risks: 1) It is possible that the Government's reform
            could falter due to policy reversal, the impact of major
            external shocks, or a continuing shortfall in external donor
            support. The Government's steadfast commitment,
            privatization of Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines, and
            efforts to expand non-mining exports will help withstand the
            risk. 2) The second risk, related to the reforms supported
            by the credit, is mitigated Government's continuing
            consultation with all major stakeholders.
